dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Did you hear that Theresa May is actually urging her own Conservative MPs to vote with the opposition?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Did you hear that Theresa May is actually urging her own Conservative MPs to vote with the opposition?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Britain's Prime Minister Boris Johnson has warned that rebel Conservative MPs risk undermining Brexit negotiations as he urged them to vote against opposition parties' plan to delay, or block a no deal exit from the European Union.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's wild—she's backing Jeremy Corbyn's plan to fast-track a no-deal Brexit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's wild-she's backing Jeremy Corbyn's plan to fast-track a no-deal Brexit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson urged MPs to vote against Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn and his pointless delay as he doubled down on his oft-repeated promise to leave the trading bloc by October 31 come what may.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And she's pushing to extend the deadline all the way to December 31st, no matter what happens.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And she's pushing to extend the deadline all the way to December thirty first, no matter what happens.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Opposition MPs are reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit delay if Johnson does not strike a deal at the European Council, a summit of EU leaders, on October 19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But she's also saying the EU thinks Britain doesn't even want a deal, which, like, makes negotiations even harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But she's also saying the E U thinks Britain doesn't even want a deal, which, like, makes negotiations even harder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He added that the chances of a deal are rising because the EU can see that Britain wants a deal, adding that the bloc may be discouraged by rebel MPs' actions, accusing them of making further negotiations absolutely impossible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And then she goes and holds an emergency cabinet meeting on Tuesday, with rumors swirling about a general election.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And then she goes and holds an emergency cabinet meeting on Tuesday, with rumors swirling about a general election.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson held an emergency cabinet meeting on Monday afternoon amid rumors the prime minister would call for a snap election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: She straight up said outside Downing Street, "I want an election, and you do want an election." That's bold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: She straight up said outside Downing Street, I want an election, and you do want an election. That's bold.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson speaking outside 10 Downing Street said: I don't want an election, you don't want an election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But isn't she also, like, offering to reward Tory rebels if they support opposition bills?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But isn't she also, like, offering to reward Tory rebels if they support opposition bills?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It follows reports that Johnson is gearing up to expel or block opposition Tory MPs from standing for election in the next election, if they support the opposition attempts to pass a law to block the U.K. from leaving the EU without a trade deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—opposition MPs are proposing a twelve-month delay if no deal is reached by October 19.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-opposition MPs are proposing a twelve-month delay if no deal is reached by October nineteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Opposition MPs are reportedly proposing a three-month Brexit delay if Johnson does not strike a deal at the European Council, a summit of EU leaders, on October 19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And all this while protesters are chanting "support the coup" outside her speech. The tension is unreal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And all this while protesters are chanting support the coup outside her speech. The tension is unreal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Protesters could be heard chanting stop the coup outside Downing Street as Johnson delivered his speech.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, if there's an election this year, it'll be the third in just four years. That's a lot of polling.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, if there's an election this year, it'll be the third in just four years. That's a lot of polling.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If an election is called this year, it would be the third in five years in the U.K., following votes in 2015 and 2017.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It feels like everything's accelerating toward some kind of breaking point, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It feels like everything's accelerating toward some kind of breaking point, you know?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And with Parliament suspended, opposition parties have almost a year to push through new laws. It's a total power struggle.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And with Parliament suspended, opposition parties have almost a year to push through new laws. It's a total power struggle.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnsons move to suspendor prorogueParliament last week under the guise of a procedure known as the Queens speech, where a government sets out its agenda for the year, means that oppositions MPs have just a week to draft a bill and secure the votes needed to make it law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Do you think she actually wants an election, or is this just political maneuvering?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Do you think she actually wants an election, or is this just political maneuvering?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to say—but she did say she desperately wants to go to the polls. Maybe she's betting on public support.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to say-but she did say she desperately wants to go to the polls. Maybe she's betting on public support.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Johnson speaking outside 10 Downing Street said: I don't want an election, you don't want an election.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Either way, it's a huge gamble.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Either way, it's a huge gamble.

artist_script:
HostA: Did you hear that Theresa May is actually urging her own Conservative MPs to vote with the opposition?
HostB: Yeah, it’s wild—she’s backing Jeremy Corbyn’s plan to fast-track a no-deal Brexit.
HostA: And she’s pushing to extend the deadline all the way to December 31st, no matter what happens.
HostB: But she’s also saying the EU thinks Britain doesn’t even want a deal, which, like, makes negotiations even harder.
HostA: Right? And then she goes and holds an emergency cabinet meeting on Tuesday, with rumors swirling about a general election.
HostB: She straight up said outside Downing Street, "I want an election, and you do want an election." That’s bold.
HostA: But isn’t she also, like, offering to reward Tory rebels if they support opposition bills?
HostB: Exactly—opposition MPs are proposing a twelve-month delay if no deal is reached by October 19.
HostA: And all this while protesters are chanting "support the coup" outside her speech. The tension is unreal.
HostB: Plus, if there’s an election this year, it’ll be the third in just four years. That’s a lot of polling.
HostA: It feels like everything’s accelerating toward some kind of breaking point, you know?
HostB: Absolutely. And with Parliament suspended, opposition parties have almost a year to push through new laws. It’s a total power struggle.
HostA: Do you think she actually wants an election, or is this just political maneuvering?
HostB: Hard to say—but she did say she desperately wants to go to the polls. Maybe she’s betting on public support.
HostA: Either way, it’s a huge gamble.
